facts.text: The property in suit is situate at Mouje Digvale, a village held by khots in the district of Ratnagiri.
The land in suit is khoti land as defined in cl. 10 of s. 3 of the Khoti Settlement Act, 1880 (Bom. Act 1 of 1880).
Ram Raghu Shirsat was the occupancy tenant of the land in suit.
Ram Raghu Shirsat sold the occupancy rights in the land in suit to Laxman Chandba Raut by a deed dated March 8, 1892.

By a compromise in a civil suit between the heirs of Laxman Chandba Raut and Tanu Daulat Gavade Sakaram, the heir of Laxman Raut got 3/5ths share and Tanu Daulat got 2/5ths share in these occupancy rights.
Dattatraya Bhikaji Khot Kulkarni, a paternal uncle of respondent number 1, purchased the shares of these persons by the sale deeds dated December 14, 1903, and February 13, 1904.
On Kulkarni's death, respondent number 1 became the owner of the property.
Respondents number 2 to 4 are the tenants of respondent number 1.

Occupancy tenant could not transfer his tenancy right without the consent of the khot, which, according to cl. 2 of s. 3, includes a mortgagee lawfully in possession of khotki and all co-sharers in a khotki.

The transferors of the afore-mentioned sale deeds of 1892 in favour of the predecessor-in-interest of respondent number 1, or of the sale deed of 1945 in favour of the appellant, did not obtain the consent of the khot before executing the deed of transfer.
Sitabai was the widow of Vishram Anna Shirsat, who succeeded Ram Raghu Shirsat, the occupancy tenant of the land in suit.
Plaintiff claimed title to the property on the basis of the sale of occupancy rights under the sale deed executed in his favour by Sitabai on February 10, 1945.
The plaintiff sued for a declaration that the property in suit was owned by him, was under his management and that the defendants had no right or interest therein.
The trial Court held the sale deed of 1892 to be a good sale deed and binding on the plaintiff and dismissed the suit.

On appeal, the Assistant Judge reversed the decree and decreed the suit holding that a transfer of the occupancy rights in the suit lands by Ram Raghu Shirsat in favour of Laxman Raut was void and that the plaintiff obtained good title under the sale deed in his favour in view of the amendment of s. 9 of the Act by s. 31 of the Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939.
Respondent number 1 preferred a second appeal to the High Court which set aside the decree of the Assistant Judge and restoring the decree of the trial Court, dismissed the suit.

High Court held that the sale deed in favour of the plaintiff too would be hit by the provisions of s.9 of the Act. It further held that the provisions of s.9 indicate that there was no absolute prohibition against a transfer of the occupancy right. A transfer by an occupancy tenant without the consent of the khot cannot be held to be void for all purposes and it would be invalid only in so far as it would be contrary to the right of the khot and not otherwise. It therefore held the transfer in favour of the respondent number 1's predecessor-in-interest in 1892 not to be void.

legal_issues.text: Whether the transfers of occupancy rights without khot consent under s.9 of the Khoti Settlement Act, 1880, are void or voidable.
Effect of the amendment to s.9 by s.31 of Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939, on the validity of the 1945 sale deed.

petitioner_arguments.text: The sale deed in favour of respondent number 1 was void and that therefore he had title to the suit land on the basis of the sale deed in his favour.

Plaintiff obtained good title under the sale deed in his favour in view of the amendment of s. 9 of the Act by s. 31 of the Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939, by which no consent of the khot was necessary for executing the sale deed in 1945.

respondent_arguments.text: Ram Raghu Shirsat lost his rights in the property in suit after he had executed the sale deed on March 8, 1892, and that, therefore the plaintiff obtained no title on the basis of the sale deed in his favour.

court_reasoning.text: Section 31 of the Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939, made amendments to s. 9 of the Act and the section after amendment reads 'The rights of khots and privileged occupants shall be heritable and transferable.' The Bombay Tenancy Act received assent on April 2, 1940, but came into force in April 1946.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 9, as it stood on February 10, 1945, made the rights of permanent tenants non-transferable without the consent of the khot.

court_reasoning.text: The sale in favour of the appellant was as much hit adversely by the provisions of s. 9 of the Act as the sale of 1892.
court_reasoning.key_observation: It is therefore not necessary to determine whether the sale was absolutely void or voidable as held by the Court below, as neither of the two sales has been challenged by the khot.

court_reasoning.text: The plaintiff has no title whether a transfer by a permanent tenant without the consent of the khot be void or voidable. If void, the sale in favour of the appellant did not convey any title to him. If merely voidable at the instance of the khot, the first sale in favour of respondent number 1's predecessor-in-interest was not avoided by the khot, and therefore validly conveyed title to him. Consequently no title passed to the plaintiff.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In either case the plaintiff fails to prove his title to the land in suit.

holdings.text: Both the 1892 sale to predecessor of respondent No.1 and the 1945 sale to appellant are invalid without khot consent under s.9 as applicable in 1945; plaintiff acquires no title.
Amendment to s.9 by Bombay Tenancy Act 1939 did not apply to 1945 sale as Act came into force in 1946.

statutes_cited.name: Khoti Settlement Act, 1880 (Bom. Act 1 of 1880)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined khoti land, khot, and prohibited transfer of occupancy rights without khot consent.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939 (Act XXIX of 1939)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended s.9 of Khoti Settlement Act to make rights heritable and transferable, but effective only from April 1946.

outcome.summary: The appeal by special leave against the Bombay High Court judgment dismissing the suit is dismissed as having no force. The plaintiff fails to prove title to the suit land.

key_quotes.text: The plaintiff has no title whether a transfer by a permanent tenant without the consent of the khot be void or voidable.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on why plaintiff fails in either interpretation.
